data.title: A Canticle for Leibowitz (Director's Cut)
data.meta_description:
A Canticle for Leibowitz (Director's Cut) by John Kannenberg, released 10 December 2016

1. FIAT HOMO 1: Overture / The Abbey in the Desert of the Southwest
2. FIAT HOMO 2: The Bookleggers / After the Flame Deluge
3. FIAT HOMO 3: Brother Francis and the Pilgrim
4. FIAT HOMO 4: Fallout Survival Shelter / Relics of the Beatus Leibowitz
5. FIAT HOMO 5: Years of Doubt / Francis Illuminates the Leibowitz Blueprint
6. FIAT HOMO 6: Highway Robbery / New Rome / Sancte Leibowitz
7. FIAT HOMO 7: Return of the Pilgrim / Death of Brother Francis Gerard of Utah
8. FIAT LUX 1: Rumors of War / Thon Taddeo and Marcus Apollo
9. FIAT LUX 2: Brother Kornhoer’s Lamp of Electrical Essence
10. FIAT LUX 3: Dom Paulo and the Hermit Benjamin
11. FIAT LUX 4: Drawing the Abbey Defenses / A Tense Dinner
12. FIAT LUX 5: Benjamin Arrives at the Abbey / War / Death of the Poet
13. FIAT VOLUNTAS TUA 1: There Were Spaceships Again in That Century
14. FIAT VOLUNTAS TUA 2: Abbott Zerchi’s Abominable Autoscribe
15. FIAT VOLUNTAS TUA 3: Mrs. Grales and Rachel
16. FIAT VOLUNTAS TUA 4: Green Star Mercy Camp / Clash with Doctor Cors
17. FIAT VOLUNTAS TUA 5: Lucifer is Fallen / Rachel is Baptized
18. FIAT VOLUNTAS TUA 6: Quo Peregrinatur Grex, Pastor Secum

A possible soundtrack for the classic science fiction novel by Walter M. Miller Jr. originally released on the Nishi netlabel in 2005, this revised Director's Cut was produced in 2016 from the original masters. 

The original novel told the story of the Earth's fall, rise, and fall after a nuclear war, following a group of monks in the desert of the Southwest of what was formerly the United States, who dedicated themselves to preserving the knowledge that had been lost after the Great Flame Deluge. The story was divided into three sections, taking place in three different time periods:

Pars PRIMA: FIAT HOMO, circa 2600 Anno Domini.
Pars SECUNDA: FIAT LUX, circa 3174 Anno Domini.
Pars TERTIA: FIAT VOLUNTAS TUA, circa 3781 Anno Domini.

My album follows the story of the book chronologically, merging music and proposed sound design for the book, which has never been adapted for film. A radio dramatisation was produced by NPR in the United States in the 1980s.
